titleText.ttltext: Norovirus outbreaks on college and university campuses

paras: Objective: To describe norovirus outbreaks at colleges and universities. Participants: None. Conducted September 2016 to March 2018. Methods: College and university norovirus outbreaks reported to the US National Outbreak Reporting System (NORS, 2009-2016) or published and indexed by @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, and Web of Science (1985-2017) were @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end. Results: Seventy-seven norovirus outbreaks were reported to NORS and 23 were identified in the @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end. Outbreaks occurred more frequently during the beginning of the school year (September-February). NORS outbreaks were more often spread by person-to-person transmission (61%) and, in published outbreaks, by food (57%). The reported exposures of published outbreaks were campus dining (n = 8) and ill food service workers (n = 7). Higher attack rates were associated with smaller on-campus population size, social networks or residences, and specific food exposures. Common control measures were communal area disinfection and health/hygiene education. Conclusions: Recommendations summarized to prevent and control norovirus outbreaks at colleges or universities.

titleText.ttltext: Meningococcal serogroups and surveillance: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and survey

paras: Background: Meningococcal disease continues to be a global public health concern due to its epidemic potential, severity, and sequelae. The global epidemiological data on circulating meningococcal serogroups have never been reviewed concurrently with the laboratory capacity for meningococcal surveillance at the national level. We, therefore, aimed to conduct a country-level review of meningococcal surveillance, serogroup distribution, and @hit_startvaccine@hit_end use. Methods: We conducted a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end across six databases to identify studies (published January 1, 2010 to October 16, 2017) and grey literature reporting meningococcal serogroup data for the years 2010-2016. We performed independent random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end for serogroups A, B, C, W, X, Y, and other. We developed and circulated a questionnaire-based survey to surveillance focal points in countries (N = 95) with known regional bacterial meningitis surveillance programs to assess their surveillance capacity and summarized using descriptive methods. Results: We included 173 studies from 59 countries in the final @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. The distribution of meningococcal serogroups differed markedly between countries and regions. Meningococcal serogroups C and W accounted for substantial proportions of meningococcal disease in most of Africa and Latin America. Serogroup B was the predominant cause of meningococcal disease in many locations in Europe, the Americas, and the Western Pacific. Serogroup Y also caused many cases of meningococcal disease in these regions, particularly in Nordic countries. Survey responses were received from 51 countries. All countries reported the ability to confirm the pathogen in-country, while approximately 30% either relied on reference laboratories for serogrouping (N = 10) or did not serogroup specimens (N = 5). Approximately half of countries did not utilize active laboratory-based surveillance system (N = 22). Nationwide use of a meningococcal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end varied, but most countries (N = 36) utilized a meningococcal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end at least for certain high-risk population groups, in private care, or during outbreaks. Conclusions: Due to the large geographical variations in circulating meningococcal serogroups, each country should continue to be monitored for changes in major disease-causing serogroups in order to inform @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and control policies. Similarly, laboratory capacity should be appropriately scaled up to more accurately understand local epidemiology and disease burden, as well as the impact of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs.

titleText.ttltext: Assessment of humoral and cell-mediated immune responses to pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end protocol

organizations: Vaccines for Africa Initiative, School of Public Health and Family Medicine, University of Cape Town

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019 Author(s) (or their employer(s)). Re-use permitted under CC BY-NC. No commercial re-use. See rights and permissions. Published by BMJ.
paras: Introduction Globally, some studies show a resurgence of pertussis. The risks and benefits of using whole-cell pertussis (wP) or acellular pertussis (aP) @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in the control of the disease have been widely debated. Better control of pertussis will require improved understanding of the immune response to pertussis @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Improved understanding and assessment of the @hit_startimmunity@hit_end induced by pertussis @hit_startvaccines@hit_end is thus imperative. Several studies have documented different immunological outcomes to pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end from an array of assays. We propose to conduct a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the different immunological assays and outcomes used in the assessment of the humoraland cell-mediated immune response following pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Methods and @hit_startanalysis@hit_end The primary outcomes for consideration are quality and quantity of immune responses (humoral and cell-mediated) post-pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Of interest as secondary outcomes are types of immunoassays used in assessing immune responses post-pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, types of biological samples used in assessing immune responses post-pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, as well as the types of antigens used to stimulate these samples during post-pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end immune response assessments. Different electronic databases (including @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end, EBSCO Host, Scopus and Web of Science) will be accessed for peer-reviewed published and grey literature evaluating immune responses to pertussis @hit_startvaccines@hit_end between 1990 and 2019. The quality of included articles will be assessed using standardised risk and quality assessment tools specific to the study design used in each article. Data extraction will be done using a data extraction form. The extracted data will be @hit_startanalysed@hit_end using STATA V.14.0 and RevMan V.5.3 software. A subgroup @hit_startanalysis@hit_end will be conducted based on the study population, type of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (wP or aP) and type of immune response (cell-mediated or humoral). Guidelines for reporting @hit_startsystematic reviews@hit_end in the revised 2009 Preferred Reporting Items for @hit_startSystematic Reviews@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-Analysis@hit_end (PRISMA) statement will be used in this study. Ethics and dissemination Ethics approval is not required for this study as it is a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end. We will only make use of data already available in the public space. Findings will be reported via publication in a peer-reviewed journal and presented at scientific meetings and workshops. Trial registration number CRD42018102455.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startVaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end diseases and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage among migrants and non-migrants worldwide: A scoping @hit_startreview@hit_end of published @hit_startliterature@hit_end, 2006 to 2016

organizations: Department of Public Health, Auckland University of Technology

paras: Background: Studies of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end disease (VPD)burden and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage among migrants compared to locally-born populations present a mixed picture on whether migrants experience disproportionate VPD rates and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end inequities, and what the associated factors are. We conducted a scoping review to explore differences in VPD burden and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage between migrants and non-migrants worldwide. Methods: We followed Arksey and O'Malley's five stage scoping review method. We searched for empirical, peer-@hit_startreviewed literature@hit_end published in English that compared VPD burden and/or @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage between migrant and non-migrant groups published between 2006 and 2016 using @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end, Sociological Abstracts, and Web of Science databases. Relevant information from the studies were charted in Microsoft Excel and results were summarised using a descriptive @hit_startanalytical@hit_end method. Results: Forty-five studies met the inclusion criteria (n = 13 reporting on VPD burden; n = 27 reporting on @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates; n = 5 reporting on both). Studies that met the criteria only reported findings from high income countries or high-middle income countries. Accounting for results that were presented according to separate ethnic migrant sub-groups, almost all of the studies comparing VPD burden (n = 17, 89%)reported higher burden among migrants compared to non-migrants, while most studies measuring @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates (n = 26, 70%)noted lower rates among migrants. Numerous factors contributed to these findings, including the influence of migrants’ nativity, socio-economic status, migration background, generation status, residential duration, cultural/personal beliefs, language proficiency and healthcare utilisation. Conclusions: Considerable variability of study foci and methodologies limited our ability to make definitive conclusions and comparisons, but the literature suggests that migrant populations generally experience higher VPD burden and lower @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates. The findings highlight a number of important considerations for future research and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end programme planning. Future research should explore factors that influence VPD burden and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates, and strategies to overcome barriers to @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake among migrants.

titleText.ttltext: PNS49 WHAT'S TRENDING? PHARMACOECONOMIC PUBLICATIONS IN THE US BETWEEN 2009–2018

paras: Objectives: To explore the rate of pharmacoeconomic publications in the US over the last 10 years, including the type of pharmacoeconomic @hit_startanalyses@hit_end conducted, disease area evaluated, perspective taken, and use of willingness-to-pay thresholds (WTPT). Methods: A pragmatic @hit_startliterature review@hit_end was conducted in @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end Epub-Ahead-of-Print, @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end In-Process and @hit_startEmbase@hit_end from January 1, 2009–November 11, 2018. Publications of cost-effectiveness, cost-utility, or budget impact (BI) @hit_startanalyses@hit_end of pharmaceuticals in the US were included. Cost-minimization and cost-benefit @hit_startanalyses@hit_end, as well as studies on screening, @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end, or devices were excluded. Abstract screening was undertaken by one reviewer, with input from a second reviewer for uncertainties. Results: Of the 8,087 records identified, 649 met the review eligibility criteria. The annual number of pharmacoeconomic publications gradually increased from 53 in 2009 to 81 in 2018. Cost-utility @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were most frequently published (68.7%), followed by cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (15.9%) and BI @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (13.6%); 1.9% presented multiple @hit_startanalyses@hit_end. 48.9% of all BI @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were published in 2017 and 2018. Oncology (29.9%), infectious diseases (15.6%), neurology (11.9%) and cardiology (10.8%) were the subject of 68.1% of publications. A private healthcare perspective was adopted in the majority of @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (59.0%); 12.6% and 10.0% of @hit_startanalyses@hit_end adopted societal and public healthcare perspectives, respectively. The most commonly-cited WTPT was $100,000/quality-adjusted life year (QALY; 36.8%); lower thresholds were also common (33.0%). Conclusions: The publication of pharmacoeconomic @hit_startanalyses@hit_end in the US has only gradually increased since 2009, despite increasing interest in health technology assessment (HTA) and the establishment of organizations such as the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review (ICER). Despite the lack of formal HTA in the US, cost-utility @hit_startanalyses@hit_end adopting the cost/QALY framework were the most frequently published, possibly mirroring HTA approaches in other countries. Further research could include assessment of publication reporting quality against guidelines such as the Consolidated Health Economic Evaluation Reporting Standards (CHEERS) checklist.

titleText.ttltext: Hepatitis B virus-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells are an important determinant of disease prognosis: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Gastroenterology, First Affiliated Hospital of Wenzhou Medical University

paras: Background: Hepatitis B virus (HBV)-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells are critical for viral clearance. To determine the effects of HBV-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells on HBV infection, we performed a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of the available literature. Methods: Electronic database searches identified appropriately designed studies that detected specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells in HBV-infected patients. Our main endpoints were the course of infection, seroconversion of HBV “e” antigen (HBeAg), the level of HBVDNA, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) activity. We used a fixed/random model for @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, according to the results of a heterogeneity test (P value of Q-squared, I@sup_begin2@sup_end). Results: Our searches found five eligible articles. Pooled estimation of the reported results showed that levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells were significantly higher in patients with acute hepatitis B than in patients with chronic hepatitis B (odds ratio [OR] = 76.30, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 15.37–378.70). With respect to chronic hepatitis B, patients with <10@sup_begin7@sup_end copies/ml HBVDNA had higher levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells relative to patients with >10@sup_begin7@sup_end copies/ml HBVDNA, but the difference had no statistics significance (OR: 3.89, 95% CI: 0.71–21.33). Patients with negative HBeAg or positive anti-HBeAg antibody (anti-HBe) results had significantly higher levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells versus patients with positive HBeAg results (OR: 5.82, 95% CI: 1.41–24.13). There were no significant associations between the levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells and serum ALT activity (OR = 0.86, 95% CI: 0.01–74.15). Conclusion: HBV-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells influence the disease activity in HBV-infected patients in various ways and determine prognosis by eliminating the virus. Therefore, efforts of studying HBV-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells focused @hit_startvaccine@hit_end are potentially needed.

titleText.ttltext: Micropapillary Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of Disease Characteristics and Treatment Outcomes

organizations: Department of Urology, Medical University of Vienna

paras: Context: The optimal treatment of urothelial bladder cancer (UBC) with micropapillary (MP) variant histology is not clear. Objective: To @hit_startreview@hit_end the current @hit_startliterature@hit_end on disease characteristics and treatment outcomes of MP UBC. Evidence acquisition: A systematic search was performed according to the Preferred Reporting Items for @hit_startSystematic Reviews@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-Analyses@hit_end statement and the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Handbook for @hit_startSystematic Reviews@hit_end of Interventions. The primary end points were recurrence-free survival (RFS), cancer-specific survival (CSS), and overall survival (OS). Evidence synthesis: We identified 758 reports comprising a total of 3154 patients, of which 28 and 15 articles were selected for qualitative and quantitative @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, respectively. In patients with T1 MP UBC, the 5-yr CSS rates for early radical cystectomy (RC) ranged from 81% to 100%, while they were between 60% and 85% for transurethral resection of the bladder and Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG). In studies reporting on neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC), the rates of complete pathological response (ypT0) ranged from 11% to 55%. Nevertheless, the use of NAC did not improve RFS (hazard ratio [HR] 1.23, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.52–2.93, p = 0.6), CSS (HR 0.9, 95% CI 0.48–1.7, p = 0.8), or OS (HR 1.35, 95% CI 0.98–1.86, p = 0.1). Fifty-three percent (95% CI 43–63%) of patients who underwent RC alone had locally advanced disease (≥pT3), and 43% (95% CI 33–52%) were harbouring lymph node metastases. MP component at RC was not significantly associated with worse RFS (HR 1.25, 95% CI 0.88–1.78, p = 0.2), CSS (HR 0.96, 95% CI 0.57–1.6, p = 0.9), or OS (HR 1.20, 95% CI 0.88–1.62, p = 0.3) when adjusted for pathological features. Conclusions: While MP UBC is associated with clinicopathological features of advanced disease, it is not associated with worse survival outcomes in patients undergoing RC. NAC results in pathological downstaging in a significant number of patients. Nevertheless, this does not translate into better survival outcomes. The optimal treatment of patients with cT1 remains controversial. Patient summary: Our results suggest that micropapillary urothelial bladder cancer does not necessarily mandate different treatment algorithms. Nevertheless, each case should be discussed individually considering other clinicopathological factors. Micropapillary urothelial carcinoma is associated with advanced pathological features but not necessarily worse outcomes. Accordingly, it does not necessarily mandate different treatment options. Nevertheless, each case should be discussed individually in a multidisciplinary approach.

titleText.ttltext: Norovirus infections and disease in lower‐middleand low‐income countries, 1997–2018

organizations: Department of Medical Virology, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Pretoria

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019 by the author. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
paras: Noroviruses are a major cause of viral gastroenteritis. The burden of the norovirus in lowresource settings is not well‐established due to limited data. This study reviews the norovirus prevalence, epidemiology, and genotype diversity in lower‐middle‐income countries (LMIC) and in low‐income countries (LIC). @hit_startPubMed@hit_end was searched up to 14 January 2019 for norovirus studies from all LIC and LMIC (World Bank Classification). Studies that tested gastroenteritis cases and/or asymptomatic controls for norovirus by reverse transcription‐polymerase chain reaction (RT‐PCR) were included. Sixty‐four studies, the majority on children <5 years of age, were identified, and 14% (95% confidence interval; CI 14–15, 5158/36,288) of the gastroenteritis patients and 8% (95% CI 7–9, 423/5310) of healthy controls tested positive for norovirus. In LMIC, norovirus was detected in 15% (95% CI 15–16) of cases and 8% (95% CI 8–10) of healthy controls. In LIC, 11% (95% CI 10–12) of symptomatic cases and 9% (95% CI 8–10) of asymptomatic controls were norovirus positive. Norovirus genogroup II predominated overall. GII.4 was the predominant genotype in all settings, followed by GII.3 and GII.6. The most prevalent GI strain was GI.3. Norovirus causes a significant amount of gastroenteritis in low‐resource countries, albeit with high levels of asymptomatic infection in LIC and a high prevalence of coinfections.

titleText.ttltext: Current antimicrobial management of community-acquired pneumonia in HIV-infected children

organizations: Department of Paediatrics and Child Health, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Cape Town and Red Cross War Memorial Children’s Hospital

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, © 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Community-acquired pneumonia is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality amongst HIV-infected infants and children. Polymicrobial infection is common and, due to the difficulties in confirming the etiology of pneumonia, empiric broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy is frequently used. Areas covered: The author based this article on literature identified from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end. The author’s search terms included: pneumonia, community-acquired pneumonia, HIV, children. The articles reviewed included original studies, recent review articles and current guidelines on the management of pneumonia in HIV-infected children. The microbiological etiology and the empiric and pathogen-specific antimicrobial therapy of community-acquired pneumonia in HIV-infected and HIV-exposed infants and children are also discussed. Expert opinion: There are many changing epidemiological factors impacting antimicrobial management of community-acquired pneumonia in the context of HIV infection in infants and children. These include @hit_startvaccination@hit_end strategies, antimicrobial prophylaxis, emerging drug-resistant pathogens, and recognition of the importance of viruses and tuberculosis in the etiology of community-acquired pneumonia. Further research is needed on optimal amtimicrobial management strategies in HIV-exposed uninfected children, and HIV-infected children receiving antiretroviral therapy.

titleText.ttltext: Clinical experience with the inactivated hepatitis A @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, Avaxim 80U Pediatric

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, © 2019 The Author(s). Published by Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Hepatitis A, caused by hepatitis A virus (HAV), is primarily transmitted via the fecal/oral route either through ingestion of contaminated food and water or through direct contact with an infectious person. Prevalence of hepatitis A is strongly correlated with socioeconomic factors, decreasing with increased socio-economic development, access to clean water and sanitation. @hit_startVaccination@hit_end against HAV should be part of a comprehensive plan for the prevention and control of viral hepatitis, either as part of regular childhood @hit_startimmunization@hit_end programs or with other recommended @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for travelers. Areas covered: We present here evidence for the immunogenicity and safety of an inactivated HAV pediatric @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (Avaxim® 80U Pediatric, Sanofi Pasteur), indicated for use in children aged 12 months to 15 years. Data evaluated are from trials undertaken during the clinical development of this @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end and post-market pharmacovigilance. Expert opinion: The pediatric HAV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end is highly immunogenic and generates long-lasting protection against hepatitis A disease in children. The safety and immunogenicity data presented in this review suggest that the pediatric HAV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end is a valuable option in the prevention of HAV infection in children in many areas of the world where the disease remains a healthcare issue.

titleText.ttltext: Trends in human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end types 16 and 18 in cervical precancers, 2008–2014

organizations: National Center for @hit_startImmunization@hit_end and Respiratory Diseases, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

paras: Background: The impact of human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end has been observed in the United States through declining cervical precancer incidence in young women. To further evaluate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end impact, we described trends in HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end types 16/18 in cervical precancers, 2008–2014. Methods: We @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end data from a 5-site, population-based surveillance system. Archived specimens from women age 18–39 years diagnosed with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grades 2–3 or adenocarcinoma in situ (CIN2þ) were tested for 37 HPV types. We described the proportion and estimated number of cases of CIN2þ by HPV-type groups over time. Trends in HPV16/18-positive CIN2þ were examined, overall and by @hit_startvaccination@hit_end status, age, histologic grade, and race/ ethnicity, using @hit_startCochrane@hit_end–Armitage tests. Results: In 10,206 cases, the proportion and estimated number of cases of HPV16/18-positive CIN2þ declined from 52.7% (1,235 cases) in 2008 to 44.1% (819 cases) in 2014 (P < 0.001). Declining trends in the proportion of HPV16/ 18-positive CIN2þ were observed among @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end (55.2%–33.3%, P < 0.001) and unvaccinated (51.0%–47.3%, P ¼ 0.03) women; ages 18–20 (48.7%–18.8%, P ¼ 0.02), 21–24 (53.8%–44.0%, P < 0.001), 25–29 (56.9%–42.4%, P < 0.001), and 30–34 (49.8%–45.8%, P ¼ 0.04) years; CIN2 (40.8%–29.9%, P < 0.001) and CIN2/3 (61.8%–46.2%, P < 0.001); non-Hispanic white (59.5%–47.9%, P < 0.001) and non-Hispanic black (40.7%–26.5%, P < 0.001). Conclusions: From 2008–2014, the proportion of HPV16/ 18-positive CIN2þ declined, with the greatest declines in @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end women; declines in unvaccinated women suggest herd protection. Impact: The declining proportion of HPV16/18-positive CIN2þ provides additional evidence of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end impact in the United States.

titleText.ttltext: Efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of a recombinant tetravalent dengue @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (CYD-TDV) in children aged 2-17 years: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

paras: Background Randomised controlled trials have evaluated the recombinant tetravalent dengue @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (CYD-TDV). However, individual results may have little power to identify differences among the populations studied. Objective To evaluate efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of CYD-TDV in the prevention of dengue in children aged 2-17 years. Design @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. Data sources @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end (from 1950 to 5 December 2018), @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end (from 1947 to 5 December 2018) and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end (from 1993 to 5 December 2018). Eligibility criteria of studies Randomised trials comparing efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of CYD-TDV with placebo or other @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for preventing dengue cases in children aged 2-17 years. Outcome measures Efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of CYD-TDV. Study appraisal and methods Calculations were made of relative risk (RR) and mean difference (MD) for dichotomous and continuous outcomes, respectively. All estimates were calculated considering a 95% CI estimate. A p<0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results Nine studies involving 34 248 participants were included. The overall efficacy of CYD-TDV was 60% (RR 0.40 (0.30 to 0.54)). Serotype-specific efficacy of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end was 51% for dengue virus type-1 (DENV-1) (RR 0.49 (0.39 to 0.63)); 34% for DENV-2 (RR 0.66 (0.50 to 0.86)); 75% for DENV-3 (RR 0.25 (0.18 to 0.35)) and 77% for DENV-4 (RR 0.23 (0.15 to 0.34)). Overall immunogenicity (MD) of CYD-TDV was 225.13 (190.34 to 259.93). Serotype-specific immunogenicity was: DENV-1: 176.59 (123.36 to 229.83); DENV-2: 294.21 (181.98 to 406.45); DENV-3: 258.78 (146.72 to 370.84) and DENV-4: 189.35 (141.11 to 237.59). The most common adverse events were headache and pain at the injection site. Limitations The main limitation of this study was unclear or incomplete data. Conclusions and implications of key findings CYD-TDV is considered safe and able to partially protect children and adolescents against four serotypes of DENV for a 1-year period. Despite this, research should prioritise improvements in @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy, thus proving higher long-term protection against all virus serotypes.

titleText.ttltext: Cost-Effectiveness of Herpes Zoster @hit_startVaccination@hit_end: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end

organizations: Center for Value-Based Care Research, Medicine Institute, Cleveland Clinic

paras: Background: Herpes zoster (HZ) is one of the most common diseases among adults. Its reactivation is characterized by a severe and painful complication. In addition to the existing herpes zoster @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (ZVL), the FDA approved a new adjuvanted subunit zoster @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (RZV) in 2017 for use in adults aged 50 years and older. Several studies have assessed the cost-effectiveness of ZVL, many of which were conducted before the long-term @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy data was available in 2014. Objective: Our objectives were to (i) summarize and compare the cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (CEAs) of ZVL conducted before and after 2014, (ii) summarize the CEAs of RZV, and (iii) critically assess the cost-effectiveness models and identify key parameters to consider for future CEAs of RZV. Methods: We searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and two other databases from inception to March 2018 for original cost-effectiveness, cost-utility, or cost-benefit @hit_startanalyses@hit_end of HZ @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Three investigators independently reviewed and assessed full-text articles after screening the titles and abstracts to determine eligibility. For all included studies, we assessed study quality using the Drummond and Jefferson's checklist and extracted study characteristics, model structure, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end characteristics, incidence of HZ and complications, incremental cost-effectiveness ratio, and sensitivity @hit_startanalyses@hit_end. We summarized data by type of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, year of publication, and funding sources. Results: Twenty-seven studies met eligibility criteria. All studies were from high-income countries and were of moderate-to-high or high quality. Twenty studies repeatedly used four cost-effectiveness models. The assumption on long-term efficacy of ZVL was not based on clinical trial data in > 50% of studies. Fifteen out of 25 studies concluded that ZVL was cost-effective compared with no @hit_startvaccine@hit_end at a @hit_startvaccine@hit_end price ranging between US$93 and US$236 per dose (2018 US$), 40% of which were published after 2014. All industry-funded studies favored the use of ZVL. The single study assessing RZV found it to be more effective and less costly than ZVL, and cost-effective compared with no @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. More studies conducted after 2014 included various efficacy endpoints for ZVL, adverse reactions, and productivity loss compared with those conducted before 2014. Conclusions: A majority of studies of ZVL found it to be cost-effective compared with no @hit_startvaccine@hit_end using the authors’ chosen willingness-to-pay thresholds. RZV was dominant in the single study comparing the two @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, but the finding needs to be confirmed with further studies in different settings. Future studies should assume @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy in line with clinical data, account for more efficacy endpoints for ZVL, and include other HZ long-term complications, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end adverse reactions, and productivity loss.

titleText.ttltext: Interventions to improve oral @hit_startvaccine@hit_end performance: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

paras: Background: Oral @hit_startvaccines@hit_end underperform in low-income and middle-income countries compared with in high-income countries. Whether interventions can improve oral @hit_startvaccine@hit_end performance is uncertain. Methods: We did a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of interventions designed to increase oral @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy or immunogenicity. We searched Ovid-@hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end and @hit_startEmbase@hit_end for trials published until Oct 23, 2017. Inclusion criteria for @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end were two or more studies per intervention category and available seroconversion data. We did random-effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end to produce summary relative risk (RR) estimates. This study is registered with PROSPERO (CRD42017060608). Findings: Of 2843 studies identified, 87 were eligible for qualitative synthesis and 66 for @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. 22 different interventions were assessed for oral poliovirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (OPV), oral rotavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (RVV), oral cholera @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (OCV), and oral typhoid @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. There was generally high heterogeneity. Seroconversion to RVV was significantly increased by delaying the first RVV dose by 4 weeks (RR 1·37, 95% CI 1·16–1·62) and OPV seroconversion was increased with monovalent or bivalent OPV compared with trivalent OPV (RR 1·51, 95% CI 1·20–1·91). Interpretation: Most strategies did not improve oral @hit_startvaccine@hit_end performance. Delaying RVV and reducing OPV valence should be considered within @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end programmes to reduce global enteric disease. New strategies to address the gap in oral @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy are urgently required. titleText.ttltext: See-Hear-Feel-Speak: A Protocol for Improving Outcomes in Emergency Department Interactions with Patients with Autism Spectrum Disorder

organizations: Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. All rights reserved.
paras: The presentation of children and adolescents with autism in the emergency department (ED) poses a unique set of challenges to clinicians and their teams, which have not yet been met. Children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) are more likely than their age and ethnically matched counterparts to visit both pediatric and general EDs and are more likely to use it for primary care complaints and dental care and to present for psychiatric concerns including suicidality. Despite the higher relative frequency, individuals with ASD demonstrate lower patient satisfaction, lower healthcare self-efficacy, and higher odds of unmet healthcare needs related to physical health, mental health, health maintenance, and @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. This can be ameliorated by simple strategies regarding communication, sensory and environmental modification, and distraction. After performing a @hit_startliterature review@hit_end of existing evidence-based recommendations via @hit_startPubMed@hit_end as well as resources from autism advocacy and self-advocacy groups, we compiled a 4-step system: "See-Hear-Feel-Speak" an approach conducive to learning with the goal of enabling clinicians and their teams to facilitate patient-centered encounters with pediatric patients with ASD. The protocol meets the practicality requirements defined by published research.

titleText.ttltext: Impact of Red Blood Cell Antigen Matching on Alloimmunization and Transfusion Complications in Patients with Sickle Cell Disease: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end

paras: Red blood cells (RBC) transfusion is critical in managing acute and chronic complications in sickle cell disease (SCD); however, it is complicated by RBC alloimmunization, iron overload, transfusion reactions and infection. Several reports documented an increased incidence of alloantibodies in transfused individuals with SCD, especially for Rh and Kell antigens. As a result, the National Institutes of Health Expert Panel and British Society for Haematology guidelines recommend primary matching for C/c, E/e and K antigens in addition to ABO/RhD for RBC transfusions. However, the evidence supporting these recommendations was cited as limited and understanding of alloimmunization in SCD is evolving. To examine the limitations of the evidence, we undertook a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of evidence behind recommendations for limited and extended serologic and genotypic RBC antigen matching to reduce alloimmunization, autoimmunization and transfusion reactions. Searches of @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end, and Web of Science databases using MeSH index and free text terms between 1976 through October 2015 and papers and captured through July 2016 through review references in papers, word of mouth, and ongoing Google Scholar and @hit_startMedline@hit_end Alerts identified 303 unique articles. Nineteen articles met inclusion criteria and were classified by the Oxford Centre Evidence Based levels of evidence. Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology checklists were completed for 18 of the 19 studies. There were no prospective randomized controlled trials. Sixteen of the articles were cohort studies, two were cross-sectional studies, and one decision tree model examining costs. Low-quality evidence from observational cohort studies supports that alloimmunization prevalence can be decreased by extending serological RBC antigen matching. Transfusion reactions are generally poorly and inconsistently reported. There was no evidence reporting the effect prophylactic genotypic matching has on alloimmunization, autoimmunization or transfusion reactions. There were no studies comparing prophylactic genotypic matching to serologic matching. High-quality evidence was lacking to support clinical decision making regarding best transfusion practices. Multicenter prospective randomized clinical trials are needed to determine best strategies for reducing the rate of alloimmunization using serologic and genotypic matching.

titleText.ttltext: Norovirus outbreaks on college and university campuses

paras: Objective: To describe norovirus outbreaks at colleges and universities. Participants: None. Conducted September 2016 to March 2018. Methods: College and university norovirus outbreaks reported to the US National Outbreak Reporting System (NORS, 2009-2016) or published and indexed by @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, and Web of Science (1985-2017) were @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end. Results: Seventy-seven norovirus outbreaks were reported to NORS and 23 were identified in the @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end. Outbreaks occurred more frequently during the beginning of the school year (September-February). NORS outbreaks were more often spread by person-to-person transmission (61%) and, in published outbreaks, by food (57%). The reported exposures of published outbreaks were campus dining (n = 8) and ill food service workers (n = 7). Higher attack rates were associated with smaller on-campus population size, social networks or residences, and specific food exposures. Common control measures were communal area disinfection and health/hygiene education. Conclusions: Recommendations summarized to prevent and control norovirus outbreaks at colleges or universities.

titleText.ttltext: Meningococcal serogroups and surveillance: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and survey

paras: Background: Meningococcal disease continues to be a global public health concern due to its epidemic potential, severity, and sequelae. The global epidemiological data on circulating meningococcal serogroups have never been reviewed concurrently with the laboratory capacity for meningococcal surveillance at the national level. We, therefore, aimed to conduct a country-level review of meningococcal surveillance, serogroup distribution, and @hit_startvaccine@hit_end use. Methods: We conducted a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end across six databases to identify studies (published January 1, 2010 to October 16, 2017) and grey literature reporting meningococcal serogroup data for the years 2010-2016. We performed independent random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end for serogroups A, B, C, W, X, Y, and other. We developed and circulated a questionnaire-based survey to surveillance focal points in countries (N = 95) with known regional bacterial meningitis surveillance programs to assess their surveillance capacity and summarized using descriptive methods. Results: We included 173 studies from 59 countries in the final @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. The distribution of meningococcal serogroups differed markedly between countries and regions. Meningococcal serogroups C and W accounted for substantial proportions of meningococcal disease in most of Africa and Latin America. Serogroup B was the predominant cause of meningococcal disease in many locations in Europe, the Americas, and the Western Pacific. Serogroup Y also caused many cases of meningococcal disease in these regions, particularly in Nordic countries. Survey responses were received from 51 countries. All countries reported the ability to confirm the pathogen in-country, while approximately 30% either relied on reference laboratories for serogrouping (N = 10) or did not serogroup specimens (N = 5). Approximately half of countries did not utilize active laboratory-based surveillance system (N = 22). Nationwide use of a meningococcal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end varied, but most countries (N = 36) utilized a meningococcal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end at least for certain high-risk population groups, in private care, or during outbreaks. Conclusions: Due to the large geographical variations in circulating meningococcal serogroups, each country should continue to be monitored for changes in major disease-causing serogroups in order to inform @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and control policies. Similarly, laboratory capacity should be appropriately scaled up to more accurately understand local epidemiology and disease burden, as well as the impact of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startVaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end diseases and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage among migrants and non-migrants worldwide: A scoping @hit_startreview@hit_end of published @hit_startliterature@hit_end, 2006 to 2016

paras: Objectives: To explore the rate of pharmacoeconomic publications in the US over the last 10 years, including the type of pharmacoeconomic @hit_startanalyses@hit_end conducted, disease area evaluated, perspective taken, and use of willingness-to-pay thresholds (WTPT). Methods: A pragmatic @hit_startliterature review@hit_end was conducted in @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end Epub-Ahead-of-Print, @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end In-Process and @hit_startEmbase@hit_end from January 1, 2009–November 11, 2018. Cost-minimization and cost-benefit @hit_startanalyses@hit_end, as well as studies on screening, @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end, or devices were excluded. Abstract screening was undertaken by one reviewer, with input from a second reviewer for uncertainties. Results: Of the 8,087 records identified, 649 met the review eligibility criteria. The annual number of pharmacoeconomic publications gradually increased from 53 in 2009 to 81 in 2018. Cost-utility @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were most frequently published (68.7%), followed by cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (15.9%) and BI @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (13.6%); 1.9% presented multiple @hit_startanalyses@hit_end. 48.9% of all BI @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were published in 2017 and 2018. Oncology (29.9%), infectious diseases (15.6%), neurology (11.9%) and cardiology (10.8%) were the subject of 68.1% of publications. A private healthcare perspective was adopted in the majority of @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (59.0%); 12.6% and 10.0% of @hit_startanalyses@hit_end adopted societal and public healthcare perspectives, respectively. The most commonly-cited WTPT was $100,000/quality-adjusted life year (QALY; 36.8%); lower thresholds were also common (33.0%). Conclusions: The publication of pharmacoeconomic @hit_startanalyses@hit_end in the US has only gradually increased since 2009, despite increasing interest in health technology assessment (HTA) and the establishment of organizations such as the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review (ICER). Despite the lack of formal HTA in the US, cost-utility @hit_startanalyses@hit_end adopting the cost/QALY framework were the most frequently published, possibly mirroring HTA approaches in other countries. Further research could include assessment of publication reporting quality against guidelines such as the Consolidated Health Economic Evaluation Reporting Standards (CHEERS) checklist.

titleText.ttltext: Hepatitis B virus-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells are an important determinant of disease prognosis: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Gastroenterology, First Affiliated Hospital of Wenzhou Medical University

paras: Background: Hepatitis B virus (HBV)-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells are critical for viral clearance. To determine the effects of HBV-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells on HBV infection, we performed a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of the available literature. Methods: Electronic database searches identified appropriately designed studies that detected specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells in HBV-infected patients. Our main endpoints were the course of infection, seroconversion of HBV “e” antigen (HBeAg), the level of HBVDNA, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) activity. We used a fixed/random model for @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, according to the results of a heterogeneity test (P value of Q-squared, I@sup_begin2@sup_end). Results: Our searches found five eligible articles. Pooled estimation of the reported results showed that levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells were significantly higher in patients with acute hepatitis B than in patients with chronic hepatitis B (odds ratio [OR] = 76.30, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 15.37–378.70). With respect to chronic hepatitis B, patients with <10@sup_begin7@sup_end copies/ml HBVDNA had higher levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells relative to patients with >10@sup_begin7@sup_end copies/ml HBVDNA, but the difference had no statistics significance (OR: 3.89, 95% CI: 0.71–21.33). Patients with negative HBeAg or positive anti-HBeAg antibody (anti-HBe) results had significantly higher levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells versus patients with positive HBeAg results (OR: 5.82, 95% CI: 1.41–24.13). There were no significant associations between the levels of specific CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells and serum ALT activity (OR = 0.86, 95% CI: 0.01–74.15). Conclusion: HBV-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells influence the disease activity in HBV-infected patients in various ways and determine prognosis by eliminating the virus. Therefore, efforts of studying HBV-specific effector CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end T cells focused @hit_startvaccine@hit_end are potentially needed.

titleText.ttltext: Micropapillary Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of Disease Characteristics and Treatment Outcomes

organizations: Department of Urology, Medical University of Vienna

paras: Context: The optimal treatment of urothelial bladder cancer (UBC) with micropapillary (MP) variant histology is not clear. Objective: To @hit_startreview@hit_end the current @hit_startliterature@hit_end on disease characteristics and treatment outcomes of MP UBC. Evidence acquisition: A systematic search was performed according to the Preferred Reporting Items for @hit_startSystematic Reviews@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-Analyses@hit_end statement and the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Handbook for @hit_startSystematic Reviews@hit_end of Interventions. The primary end points were recurrence-free survival (RFS), cancer-specific survival (CSS), and overall survival (OS). Evidence synthesis: We identified 758 reports comprising a total of 3154 patients, of which 28 and 15 articles were selected for qualitative and quantitative @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, respectively. In patients with T1 MP UBC, the 5-yr CSS rates for early radical cystectomy (RC) ranged from 81% to 100%, while they were between 60% and 85% for transurethral resection of the bladder and Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG). In studies reporting on neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC), the rates of complete pathological response (ypT0) ranged from 11% to 55%. Nevertheless, the use of NAC did not improve RFS (hazard ratio [HR] 1.23, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.52–2.93, p = 0.6), CSS (HR 0.9, 95% CI 0.48–1.7, p = 0.8), or OS (HR 1.35, 95% CI 0.98–1.86, p = 0.1). Fifty-three percent (95% CI 43–63%) of patients who underwent RC alone had locally advanced disease (≥pT3), and 43% (95% CI 33–52%) were harbouring lymph node metastases. MP component at RC was not significantly associated with worse RFS (HR 1.25, 95% CI 0.88–1.78, p = 0.2), CSS (HR 0.96, 95% CI 0.57–1.6, p = 0.9), or OS (HR 1.20, 95% CI 0.88–1.62, p = 0.3) when adjusted for pathological features. Conclusions: While MP UBC is associated with clinicopathological features of advanced disease, it is not associated with worse survival outcomes in patients undergoing RC. NAC results in pathological downstaging in a significant number of patients. Nevertheless, this does not translate into better survival outcomes. The optimal treatment of patients with cT1 remains controversial. Patient summary: Our results suggest that micropapillary urothelial bladder cancer does not necessarily mandate different treatment algorithms. Nevertheless, each case should be discussed individually considering other clinicopathological factors. Micropapillary urothelial carcinoma is associated with advanced pathological features but not necessarily worse outcomes. Accordingly, it does not necessarily mandate different treatment options. Nevertheless, each case should be discussed individually in a multidisciplinary approach.

titleText.ttltext: Norovirus infections and disease in lower‐middleand low‐income countries, 1997–2018

organizations: Department of Medical Virology, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Pretoria

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019 by the author. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
paras: Noroviruses are a major cause of viral gastroenteritis. The burden of the norovirus in lowresource settings is not well‐established due to limited data. This study reviews the norovirus prevalence, epidemiology, and genotype diversity in lower‐middle‐income countries (LMIC) and in low‐income countries (LIC). @hit_startPubMed@hit_end was searched up to 14 January 2019 for norovirus studies from all LIC and LMIC (World Bank Classification). Studies that tested gastroenteritis cases and/or asymptomatic controls for norovirus by reverse transcription‐polymerase chain reaction (RT‐PCR) were included. Sixty‐four studies, the majority on children <5 years of age, were identified, and 14% (95% confidence interval; CI 14–15, 5158/36,288) of the gastroenteritis patients and 8% (95% CI 7–9, 423/5310) of healthy controls tested positive for norovirus. In LMIC, norovirus was detected in 15% (95% CI 15–16) of cases and 8% (95% CI 8–10) of healthy controls. In LIC, 11% (95% CI 10–12) of symptomatic cases and 9% (95% CI 8–10) of asymptomatic controls were norovirus positive. Norovirus genogroup II predominated overall. GII.4 was the predominant genotype in all settings, followed by GII.3 and GII.6. The most prevalent GI strain was GI.3. Norovirus causes a significant amount of gastroenteritis in low‐resource countries, albeit with high levels of asymptomatic infection in LIC and a high prevalence of coinfections.

titleText.ttltext: Current antimicrobial management of community-acquired pneumonia in HIV-infected children

organizations: Department of Paediatrics and Child Health, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Cape Town and Red Cross War Memorial Children’s Hospital

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, © 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Community-acquired pneumonia is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality amongst HIV-infected infants and children. Polymicrobial infection is common and, due to the difficulties in confirming the etiology of pneumonia, empiric broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy is frequently used. Areas covered: The author based this article on literature identified from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end. The author’s search terms included: pneumonia, community-acquired pneumonia, HIV, children. The articles reviewed included original studies, recent review articles and current guidelines on the management of pneumonia in HIV-infected children. The microbiological etiology and the empiric and pathogen-specific antimicrobial therapy of community-acquired pneumonia in HIV-infected and HIV-exposed infants and children are also discussed. Expert opinion: There are many changing epidemiological factors impacting antimicrobial management of community-acquired pneumonia in the context of HIV infection in infants and children. These include @hit_startvaccination@hit_end strategies, antimicrobial prophylaxis, emerging drug-resistant pathogens, and recognition of the importance of viruses and tuberculosis in the etiology of community-acquired pneumonia. Further research is needed on optimal amtimicrobial management strategies in HIV-exposed uninfected children, and HIV-infected children receiving antiretroviral therapy.

Prevalence of hepatitis A is strongly correlated with socioeconomic factors, decreasing with increased socio-economic development, access to clean water and sanitation. @hit_startVaccination@hit_end against HAV should be part of a comprehensive plan for the prevention and control of viral hepatitis, either as part of regular childhood @hit_startimmunization@hit_end programs or with other recommended @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for travelers. Areas covered: We present here evidence for the immunogenicity and safety of an inactivated HAV pediatric @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (Avaxim® 80U Pediatric, Sanofi Pasteur), indicated for use in children aged 12 months to 15 years. Data evaluated are from trials undertaken during the clinical development of this @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end and post-market pharmacovigilance. Expert opinion: The pediatric HAV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end is highly immunogenic and generates long-lasting protection against hepatitis A disease in children. The safety and immunogenicity data presented in this review suggest that the pediatric HAV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end is a valuable option in the prevention of HAV infection in children in many areas of the world where the disease remains a healthcare issue.

titleText.ttltext: Trends in human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end types 16 and 18 in cervical precancers, 2008–2014

organizations: National Center for @hit_startImmunization@hit_end and Respiratory Diseases, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

paras: Background: The impact of human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end has been observed in the United States through declining cervical precancer incidence in young women. To further evaluate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end impact, we described trends in HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end types 16/18 in cervical precancers, 2008–2014. Methods: We @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end data from a 5-site, population-based surveillance system. Archived specimens from women age 18–39 years diagnosed with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grades 2–3 or adenocarcinoma in situ (CIN2þ) were tested for 37 HPV types. We described the proportion and estimated number of cases of CIN2þ by HPV-type groups over time. Trends in HPV16/18-positive CIN2þ were examined, overall and by @hit_startvaccination@hit_end status, age, histologic grade, and race/ ethnicity, using @hit_startCochrane@hit_end–Armitage tests. Results: In 10,206 cases, the proportion and estimated number of cases of HPV16/18-positive CIN2þ declined from 52.7% (1,235 cases) in 2008 to 44.1% (819 cases) in 2014 (P < 0.001). Declining trends in the proportion of HPV16/ 18-positive CIN2þ were observed among @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end (55.2%–33.3%, P < 0.001) and unvaccinated (51.0%–47.3%, P ¼ 0.03) women; ages 18–20 (48.7%–18.8%, P ¼ 0.02), 21–24 (53.8%–44.0%, P < 0.001), 25–29 (56.9%–42.4%, P < 0.001), and 30–34 (49.8%–45.8%, P ¼ 0.04) years; CIN2 (40.8%–29.9%, P < 0.001) and CIN2/3 (61.8%–46.2%, P < 0.001); non-Hispanic white (59.5%–47.9%, P < 0.001) and non-Hispanic black (40.7%–26.5%, P < 0.001). Impact: The declining proportion of HPV16/18-positive CIN2þ provides additional evidence of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end impact in the United States.

titleText.ttltext: Efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of a recombinant tetravalent dengue @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (CYD-TDV) in children aged 2-17 years: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

paras: Background Randomised controlled trials have evaluated the recombinant tetravalent dengue @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (CYD-TDV). Eligibility criteria of studies Randomised trials comparing efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of CYD-TDV with placebo or other @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for preventing dengue cases in children aged 2-17 years. titleText.ttltext: Cost-Effectiveness of Herpes Zoster @hit_startVaccination@hit_end: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end

organizations: Center for Value-Based Care Research, Medicine Institute, Cleveland Clinic

paras: Background: Herpes zoster (HZ) is one of the most common diseases among adults. Its reactivation is characterized by a severe and painful complication. In addition to the existing herpes zoster @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (ZVL), the FDA approved a new adjuvanted subunit zoster @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (RZV) in 2017 for use in adults aged 50 years and older. Several studies have assessed the cost-effectiveness of ZVL, many of which were conducted before the long-term @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy data was available in 2014. Objective: Our objectives were to (i) summarize and compare the cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (CEAs) of ZVL conducted before and after 2014, (ii) summarize the CEAs of RZV, and (iii) critically assess the cost-effectiveness models and identify key parameters to consider for future CEAs of RZV. Methods: We searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and two other databases from inception to March 2018 for original cost-effectiveness, cost-utility, or cost-benefit @hit_startanalyses@hit_end of HZ @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Three investigators independently reviewed and assessed full-text articles after screening the titles and abstracts to determine eligibility. For all included studies, we assessed study quality using the Drummond and Jefferson's checklist and extracted study characteristics, model structure, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end characteristics, incidence of HZ and complications, incremental cost-effectiveness ratio, and sensitivity @hit_startanalyses@hit_end. We summarized data by type of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, year of publication, and funding sources. Results: Twenty-seven studies met eligibility criteria. All studies were from high-income countries and were of moderate-to-high or high quality. Twenty studies repeatedly used four cost-effectiveness models. The assumption on long-term efficacy of ZVL was not based on clinical trial data in > 50% of studies. Fifteen out of 25 studies concluded that ZVL was cost-effective compared with no @hit_startvaccine@hit_end at a @hit_startvaccine@hit_end price ranging between US$93 and US$236 per dose (2018 US$), 40% of which were published after 2014. All industry-funded studies favored the use of ZVL. The single study assessing RZV found it to be more effective and less costly than ZVL, and cost-effective compared with no @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. More studies conducted after 2014 included various efficacy endpoints for ZVL, adverse reactions, and productivity loss compared with those conducted before 2014. Conclusions: A majority of studies of ZVL found it to be cost-effective compared with no @hit_startvaccine@hit_end using the authors’ chosen willingness-to-pay thresholds. RZV was dominant in the single study comparing the two @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, but the finding needs to be confirmed with further studies in different settings. Future studies should assume @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy in line with clinical data, account for more efficacy endpoints for ZVL, and include other HZ long-term complications, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end adverse reactions, and productivity loss.

paras: Background: Oral @hit_startvaccines@hit_end underperform in low-income and middle-income countries compared with in high-income countries. Findings: Of 2843 studies identified, 87 were eligible for qualitative synthesis and 66 for @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. 22 different interventions were assessed for oral poliovirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (OPV), oral rotavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (RVV), oral cholera @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (OCV), and oral typhoid @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. The protocol meets the practicality requirements defined by published research.

titleText.ttltext: Impact of Red Blood Cell Antigen Matching on Alloimmunization and Transfusion Complications in Patients with Sickle Cell Disease: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end

paras: Red blood cells (RBC) transfusion is critical in managing acute and chronic complications in sickle cell disease (SCD); however, it is complicated by RBC alloimmunization, iron overload, transfusion reactions and infection. Several reports documented an increased incidence of alloantibodies in transfused individuals with SCD, especially for Rh and Kell antigens. As a result, the National Institutes of Health Expert Panel and British Society for Haematology guidelines recommend primary matching for C/c, E/e and K antigens in addition to ABO/RhD for RBC transfusions. However, the evidence supporting these recommendations was cited as limited and understanding of alloimmunization in SCD is evolving. To examine the limitations of the evidence, we undertook a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of evidence behind recommendations for limited and extended serologic and genotypic RBC antigen matching to reduce alloimmunization, autoimmunization and transfusion reactions. Searches of @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end, and Web of Science databases using MeSH index and free text terms between 1976 through October 2015 and papers and captured through July 2016 through review references in papers, word of mouth, and ongoing Google Scholar and @hit_startMedline@hit_end Alerts identified 303 unique articles. Nineteen articles met inclusion criteria and were classified by the Oxford Centre Evidence Based levels of evidence. Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology checklists were completed for 18 of the 19 studies. There were no prospective randomized controlled trials. Sixteen of the articles were cohort studies, two were cross-sectional studies, and one decision tree model examining costs. Low-quality evidence from observational cohort studies supports that alloimmunization prevalence can be decreased by extending serological RBC antigen matching. Transfusion reactions are generally poorly and inconsistently reported. There was no evidence reporting the effect prophylactic genotypic matching has on alloimmunization, autoimmunization or transfusion reactions. There were no studies comparing prophylactic genotypic matching to serologic matching. High-quality evidence was lacking to support clinical decision making regarding best transfusion practices. Multicenter prospective randomized clinical trials are needed to determine best strategies for reducing the rate of alloimmunization using serologic and genotypic matching.
